Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Singapore
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Justin Wilcox of the University of Notre Dame to conduct a research project in Biology during the summer of 2013 at Duke-NUS Medical school in Singapore. The project title is "Exploring the Role of Parasitic Worms in Enzoic Disease Transmission." The host scientists are Dr. Gavin Smith and Dr. Ian Mendenhall.

Parasitic worms (i.e. helminthes) are known to increase the pathology and transmission of several important diseases (including HIV infection, Tuberculosis, Hepatitis C) through modulation of host immunity during simultaneous coinfection. However, the commonality of such interactions between helminthes and micropathogens is not well known due to uncertainties regarding the mechanisms of immune modulation by parasitic worms. To address this shortcoming, this project is exploring the importance of different types of helminth infection to microparasite immunity in a wild population of long-tailed macaques living in close association with humans in Singapore. Through the comparative assessment of immunomodulatory abilities of different helminthes, the results may ultimately allow for new insights into the control of infectious disease, and the use of helminthes in the treatment of autoimmune disease.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. This study will be directly relevant to the management of non-human primate populations by identifying their capacity to act as a reservoir for important human pathogens, and factors that increase or decrease this reservoir potential. The findings are being presented to the Department of Biological Sciences at the University of Notre Dame, and prepared for publication in a peer reviewed journal.

This grant funded research on parasitic infections of long-tailed macaques living on the island of Singapore.  Fresh macaque fecal samples were collected from several sites within Singapore.  These samples were tested for parasitic worms at Duke-NUS Graduate Medical School in Singapore shortly following collection.   A portion of each sample was also fixed in formalin and mailed back to the University of Notre Dame in South Bend, Indiana, for further parasitological testing.  Frozen portions of each sample were also mailed to the united states for genetic analysis of parasites in these samples and other additional testing.  DNA was also extracted from these samples in Singapore for genetic analysis of parasites.  While data collection continues, these samples will be used to genetically assess transmission of intestinal parasites, including human pathogens, within Singapore's macaques and between Singapores macaques and other animals.  They will also be used to  assess the influence of human diet on the parasite communities of Singapore's macaques.

 

The information collected and being collected as a part of this project is important for several reasons.  The first data set of parasitic worm infections of macaques in Singapore has been collected through this project.  It was found that Singapore's macaques contain far fewer parasitic worms than macaques elsewhere in terms of the number of species and the number of proportion of individuals infected.  It was also found that the distributions of these worms vary significantly between groups of these monkeys.  This information will be used produce and to inform additional ongoing researh on why parasite burdens are lower in Singapore's macaques, and what factors structure this parasite community.  A major focus of this ongoing research is the determination of how human impacts, particularly the availability of human food sources and the introduction of invasive species may increase or decrease the transmission of human parasites within macaques.  This informaiton may be important to the management of wildlife in Singapore and elsewhere.  It is also directly applicable to the management of non-human primates in general.  This fellowship has already allowed for more informed management of Singapore's macaques.  During my time in Singapore I was able to attend a meeting on macaque management held by the Singapore National Parks Board that was faciliated through a collaborator, Dr. Agustin Fuentes.  At this meeting I presented previously collected data on protozoan parasites of macaques in Singapore, the first and only such data set for these macaques, and highlighted trends in this data that suggested a role of recently introduced feral boars in transmission of a potential human pathogens to macaques.  This has led to a new project on cross parasite important as the managerment and conservation of these animals is an increasingly important and controversial subject within Singapore.
